docs/example.html.title: Example program | TabScript
docs/example.html.summary: Example program Here is a program showing virtually all features: //Importing the standard library for print import stdlib; //Table variables tab global = ["h", "e", "l", "l", "o"]; //Table appending tab greeting = global + " " + "world"; print(greeting); //hello world //Dollar strings with full expressions tab doll = $"The message of the day is '{greeting + "!"}'"; print(doll); //The message of the day is 'hello world!' //True and false handled with length: 0 is false, > 0 is true tab true = ["anything"]; tab false = []; //If statements if true{ print("true"); //true } if false{ print("false"); } //String literals are handled like length 1 tables: tab eq = "abcd" == ["abcd"]; //Ternary operators print(eq ? "equal" : "not equal"); //equal //! operator: returns [] (false) when the table has length greater than zero and [""] (true) when length is 0. This is the general concept of truthiness tab t = !["h"]; //- operator: removes elements tab h = ["a", "a", "b"] - ["a"]; print(h); //ab //Equality print(["a", "b"] == "ab" ? "true" : "false"); //false print(["a", "b"] != "ab" ? "true" : "false"); //true //^ operator: joins all elements into a single string print(["a", "b", "c"]^ == "abc" ? "true" : "false"); //true //% operator: separates all charachters of all elements into their own elements print(["a", "b", "c"] == "abc"% ? "true" : "false"); //true //@ operator: checks if all elements are contained print(["a", "b"] @ ["c", "d", "a", "n", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //true //Element access tab abc = ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"]; print(abc.0); //a print(abc.1); //b print(abc.-1); //Last element: f print(abc.-2); //Previous element: e print(abc.random); //Random element print(abc.100); //Obviously out of bounds, returns "" print(abc.-100); //Obviously out of bounds, returns "" //Element setting tab nums = ["0", "2", "3"]; nums.0 = "1"; print(nums); //123 //Literal building: flattening of other tables tab all = [abc, "+", nums, ["j", ["k", "l", abc], "k"]]; print(all); //abcdef+123jklabcdefk //Numbers are tables as well: 2 is the same as ["", ""], with empty strings and length 2. print(3); //Nothing will be seen (empty strings) //<, <=, >, >= operators: they compare length print(["1"] > ["a", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //false print(4 > ["a", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //true //length: retuns a number table of the length: ["a", "b"].length => ["", ""] (2); print(2 == ["a", "b"].length ? "true" : "false"); //true //While statements with else clauses(if no break was invoked) tab i = 0; while i < 5{ print("elem"); i += 1; }else{ print("finish"); } //Range access: index, length. Handles negative indexes, negative lengths and expressions print(abc[0, 3]); //abc print(abc[1, 3]); //bcd print(abc[1, 300]); //Out of bounds, auto crops: bcdef print(abc[-1, 1]); //f print(abc[-1, -1]); //e print(abc[random, 2]); //random consecutive elements print(abc[1 + ["n", "t"], 1]); //Expression: d //Do statements with optionally else clause i = 0; do{ print("do"); i += 1; }while i < 6; print("next loop"); //next loop i = 0; do{ print("do"); i += 1; }while i < 6 else{ print("finish do"); } //Foreach foreach letter @ abc + nums{ print(letter); } //Grouping with () tab g = (abc + "k")%.length > (16 - (4 + 2)); print(g ? "true" : "false"); //false //Lexical scoping tab k = "out"; if 1{ print(k); //out tab k = "in"; print(k); //in } print(k); //out //Function call print(plusA("h")); //ha //Implicit return print(retNone() == [] ? "true" : "false"); //true //Global var access tab glob = "hi"; print(greet()); //hi //Self function call print(abc.decorate()); //eeeeee //Alternate self funcion call print(decorate(abc)); //eeeeee //Function overloading print(fibonacci(10).decorate()); //eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee print(fibonacci(20, 3)); //sorry //stdlib includes a function called 'upper' to turn tables into uppercase. However, we declared a function called the same. See what happens when declaring the import: print("j".upper()); //oops print("j".stdlib::upper()); //J print("j".local::upper()); //oops //Complex funcion usage + library functions print(join([getDate()[0, 3].join("/"), getDate()[3, 3].join(":")], " ")); //Todays date //Exiting the script compeltely(not needed at the end, used for early exit, maybe even in a function) exit; //Functions go AFTER all of the program function plusA(t){ return t + "a"; } function retNone(){ print("hello!"); //Implicitly returns [] } function greet(){ return glob; } function fibonacci(n){ if n <= 1{ return n; } //Recursion return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2); } function fibonacci(n, k){ return "sorry"; } //Self function function decorate(self){ tab i = 0; tab r; while i < self{ r += "e"; i += 1; } return r; } //Local function function upper(self){ return "oops"; }

docs/introduction.html.title: Introduction | TabScript
docs/introduction.html.summary: Introduction Using the scripting language without any aditional features is very straightforward: //Needed import using TabScript; class Program{ static void Main(){ //Get source string src = File.ReadAllText("program.tbs"); try{ TableScript script = TableScript.FromSource(src); script.Run(new Table()); }catch(TabScriptException ex){ Console.Error.WriteLine(ex); } } } Use a custom IImportResolver to add features in the form of imports

index.html.title: TableScript | TabScript
index.html.summary: TableScript TableScript is a string-based scripting languange. This library built in C# provides an API to use interpret TableScript programs. You can go to the Introduction for starting. You can also check the API for the code usage details.
